work.p: This line is a draft of a line from the third poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, ultimately titled "To Think of Time": "The prostitute is not nothing . . . . the mocker of religion is not nothing as he goes" (1855, p. 68). The line does not appear in the final version of the poem.

The words "attraction of gravity" in this manuscript appear in two contexts in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. The closest in meaning to its use in this manuscript is in the poem later titled "Great Are the Myths": "It cannot be varied by statutes, any more than love, pride, the attraction of gravity, can" (1855, p. 251). "Great Are the Myths" was ultimately shortened to a few lines and published as "Youth, Day, Old Age, and Night" in the 1881 Leaves of Grass.

titleStmt.title: Are the prostitutes nothing
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably written between 1850 and 1855 when Whitman was composing his first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. It includes a draft of a line from the third poem in that edition, eventually titled "To Think of Time."

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: You lusty and graceflu [sic] youth! you are great
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from a digital image of the original manuscript.
On the back of this leaf is a partial draft of the final poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, ultimately titled "Great Are the Myths."

revisionDesc.change: tweaked wording of work note for "Youth, Day, Old Age, and Night"
divided text into separate files, corrected
Added third digit to leaf numbers
Updated markup of gap and unclear elements
Addition of Date and Work Markup

lg.l:
Are the prostitutes nothing? Are the
mockers of religion nothing?

del.l:
Does the light or heat pick out? Does
the attraction o of gravity pick out?

div1.ab:
(In remarks on myself
What they say of him

—he was just like other men—he shall
not be singled out.
